chapter.title: 68 Ehrlichia, Anaplasma, and Related Intracellular Bacteria

sect1.title: 68 Ehrlichia, Anaplasma, and Related Intracellular Bacteria

para.phrase: ELITZA S. THEEL AND BOBBI S. PRITT

sect1.para: The familyAnaplasmataceae in the order Rickettsiales is composed of several genera of clinically significant bacteria encompassing both human and veterinary pathogens (1). Members of the genera Ehrlichia and Anaplasma are the best known, having been recognized as agents of veterinary importance for over a century and as human pathogens since 1987 (2, 3). Members of the genera Neorickettsia and “Candidatus Neoehrlichia” are also known to be human and veterinary pathogens, and Wolbachia species are important endosymbionts of most human filarial parasites (4–8). This chapter focuses on the clinically relevant members of the Anaplasmataceae, with particular emphasis on Anaplasma phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia chaffeensis, the most common human pathogens in this family.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Anaplasmataceae is a family of obligately intracellular bacteria in the phylum Proteobacteria, section alpha (alphaproteobacteria), order Rickettsiales. Taxonomic classification of the rickettsias (Fig. 1) is based largely upon sequence analysis of the 16S rRNA gene and groEL (heat shock operon) (1) and, increasingly, on fully sequenced genomes (9). Phenotypic characteristics such as serologic cross-reactions, similarities among major immunodominant surface proteins, and cellular tropisms of these bacteria further support the phylogenetic approach (10, 11). Minor sequence differences in 16S rRNA genes exist among some members of the Anaplasmataceae that are markers of their biological and ecological differences (12–14). For example, genetic variants of Anaplasma phagocytophilum exist among ticks and mammals in the northeastern United States and Europe, including some that probably do not cause disease in humans (14–16).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA
sect2.para: The familyAnaplasmataceae contains small, nonmotile, pleomorphic, obligately intracellular bacteria that reside and propagate within host membrane-derived vacuoles in the host cell cytoplasm (17). The family is divided into at least 4 major clades representing separate genera: Ehrlichia, Anaplasma, Wolbachia, and Neorickettsia (1). Also in this family are “Candidatus Neoehrlichia,” which contains the human pathogen “Candidatus Neoehrlichia mikurensis” (5), and the potential genus Aegyptianella (currently listed as incertae sedis [uncertain taxonomic status]), which is most closely related to Anaplasma (18). Although they are Gram-negative organisms, some Anaplasmataceae members (e.g., Ehrlichia, Anaplasma, and Neorickettsia species) lack the genes necessary for lipopolysaccharide and peptidoglycan synthesis (19). Table 1 describes important characteristics of select human and veterinary pathogens in the family Anaplasmataceae.

All members of theAnaplasmataceae except Wolbachia spp. can multiply in vertebrate host cells and have at least one identified invertebrate vector host (17). The most commonly infected cells in vertebrate hosts are of hematopoietic origin; Anaplasma and Ehrlichia species infect cells of different hematopoietic lineages in different animal hosts, including granulocytes, monocytes, erythrocytes, and platelets (17). Other Ehrlichia species (e.g., Ehrlichia ruminantium and E. muris) also infect endothelial cells. Neorickettsia spp. most commonly infect mononuclear phagocytes but can also infect enterocytes in mammalian hosts, as well as various trematode and insect cells (20, 21), while Wolbachia spp. infect arthropod and helminth gonadal cells (22–24). Recently, “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” was cultivated in human endothelial cell lines derived from the dermal microvasculature and pulmonary artery, which may indicate its in vivo target cell type (25).

TheAnaplasmataceae gain entry to the host cells through adhesion and endocytosis. As they propagate within vacuoles, they form mulberry-like clusters referred to as morulae (L. morum, mulberry) (Fig. 2), which are visible by light microscopy (17). Continued multiplication eventually results in cell lysis or exocytosis and release of bacteria, allowing continued infection of other competent cells (26). Characteristics of the cytoplasmic vacuole, including its relationship to the host cell mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum, number of enclosed bacteria, and whether the bacteria are encompassed in a fibrillary matrix, vary by genus (8, 17, 27–29).

As seen in transmission electron-microscopic studies,Anaplasma, Ehrlichia, and Neorickettsia species have two distinct morphologic forms: a small, compact dense-core form measuring 0.2 to 0.4 μm and a larger reticulate body (Anaplasma and Ehrlichia) or “lighter” form (Neorickettsia) measuring 0.8 to 1.5 μm (27). The infective dense-core forms of Anaplasma and Ehrlichia species differentially express specific ligands on their surface which enable cell adhesion and facilitate endocytosis. These ligands are not present on the metabolically active reticulate forms. Both dense-core and reticulate forms can be found within vacuoles and are capable of binary fission; this suggests that there is asynchronous development of infectious from noninfectious forms (28). Wolbachia species also exhibit pleomorphic morphology within infected hosts, appearing as small coccoid forms (0.25 to 1 μm in diameter) and ellipsoidal forms (0.5 to 1.3 μm long) (23). “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” has been observed as small cocci within membrane-bound cytoplasmic inclusions of endothelial cells of infected rodents (5).

sect2.para: Like other rickettsiae, members of theAnaplasmataceae have a reduced genome size and rely on host cell machinery for survival. Whole-genome shotgun sequencing of more than 75 Anaplasmataceae members has shown that genomes range from 0.86 Mb in Neorickettsia sennetsu to 1.18 Mb in Ehrlichia chaffeensis and 1.77 Mb in Anaplasma phagocytophilum (19). While this study did not include Wolbachia genomes, a recent review demonstrated significant genome size variability, ranging from 0.44 to 3.09 Mb (24). Genome sequencing identifies a low G+C content common to endosymbionts (except for Anaplasma marginale) and a large proportion of noncoding sequences (19). In contrast to the reductive evolution seen in other intracellular bacteria, Anaplasmataceae prokaryotes have many paralogous genes, which document partial gene duplication events (19). Active duplication of tandemly repeated sequences likely results in new genes encoding outer membrane proteins, leading to antigenic variation, immune evasion, and thereby enhanced survival. The Anaplasmataceae also possess partially duplicated genes that encode an anomalous type IV secretion system that most likely contributes to virulence, perhaps by transport of effectors into the host cell or by DNA uptake or in conjugation (30).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Genera that make up theAnaplasmataceae can be classified by whether they are transmitted by ticks; Ehrlichia, Anaplasma, and “Candidatus Neoehrlichia” spp. are tick-borne pathogens, while Neorickettsia sennetsu and Wolbachia spp. are not. Rather than tick transmission, Neorickettsia sennetsu is thought to be acquired by humans following ingestion of fish infested with infected digenean trematodes (flukes), but some pathogenic veterinary Neorickettsia species can be acquired by consumption of aquatic insects that harbor trematode metacercariae (21, 31). Wolbachia spp. are not currently known to cause human disease but are important endosymbionts of a broad range of arthropods, helminths, and crustaceans, including disease-causing filaria (22, 23). They are found in all stages of filarial nematodes and are transmitted vertically after infection of the helminth ovary (7, 32).

Ticks become infected withEhrlichia, Anaplasma, and “Ca. Neoehrlichia” species when larvae or nymphs ingest these bacteria while feeding on an infected animal. Transovarial transmission has not been described, but transstadial transmission is well recognized. Newly infected ticks molt into the next life cycle stage after feeding and can then transmit the bacteria to a new mammalian host. Both ticks and nonhuman mammals serve as reservoirs (33, 34). In contrast, humans are accidental, dead-end hosts. Therefore, maintenance of tick-borne infection in nature depends upon the presence of appropriate tick vectors and mammalian hosts in the local environment (34–36) (Table 1). The epidemiology of each tick-borne infection reflects the seasonal activities and geographic distribution of the associated vectors and hosts. In the United States, cases of ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis can occur in any month, but most are reported during April through September, with peak reports in June and July, coinciding with the corresponding levels of the tick vector’s host-seeking and feeding activities (37–40).

sect1.title: Anaplasmosis (Human Granulocytic Anaplasmosis)
sect1.para: Anaplasmosis (previously known as human granulocytic ehrlichiosis [HGE]) is the most widespread of the tick-transmitted human diseases due to members of theAnaplasmataceae. The causative agent was initially known as Rickettsia phagocytophila and later as Ehrlichia phagocytophila, before being renamed Anaplasma phagocytophilum based on phylogenetic studies (1). Most cases occur in the United States, but increasing numbers of cases are reported in Canada, Europe (primarily Scandinavia and Central Europe), and eastern regions of Asia (16, 41–44). A. phagocytophilum is vectored by ticks in the Ixodes persulcatus complex, including Ixodes scapularis (the black-legged tick or deer tick) in the northeastern and upper midwestern United States, I. pacificus (the pacific black-legged tick) in the northwestern United States, and I. ricinus (the castor bean tick) and I. persulcatus (the taiga tick) in Europe (41–44). Ixodes persulcatus is also the vector in Asia. Importantly, these ticks are also vectors for members of the Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato complex (causative agents of Lyme borreliosis) and several viral, bacterial, and parasitic pathogens, and more than one of these pathogens can be transmitted by the tick to its host during feeding (39, 45). Other ticks may also serve as vectors for A. phagocytophilum; for example, Haemaphysalis concinna has been implicated as a vector in eastern Asia (46). Less common means of transmission to humans are blood product transfusion (47, 48), solid organ transplantation (48), and perinatal transmission (49).

Human anaplasmosis was first recognized in 1990 in a patient residing in Wisconsin (12) but did not become a nationally notifiable disease in the United States until 1999, and the number of reported cases has mostly increased each year since then (39). In Europe, the first recognized case of human anaplasmosis was in 1997 in a patient residing in Slovenia (50). Prior to these first cases, A. phagocytophilum had been known to infect domestic ruminants in Europe and horses in the United States since the mid-20th century (16). There were 5,655 cases of confirmed or probable anaplasmosis reported to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in 2019 (37, 39, 45). These case counts are slightly above those reported for the spotted fever group rickettsioses (including Rocky Mountain spotted fever) in the United States in 2019 (n = 5,207), making anaplasmosis the second most common tick-borne disease in the United States, after Lyme disease (51). Cases were reported from 37 states and from New York City, with most cases being from states in the Upper Midwest and northeastern seaboard. New York, Massachusetts, Maine, Vermont, Minnesota, Wisconsin, New Hampshire, and Connecticut accounted for almost 9 of 10 reported cases of anaplasmosis in 2019, with Vermont having the highest incidence rate per million persons at risk (857.4) (39). Males and individuals over the age of 40 have the highest frequency of reported disease. Of note, anaplasmosis has a bimodal seasonality; symptom onset is primarily during the spring and summer months (May through August) corresponding to the peak time of the nymphs’ host-seeking behavior, but there is a smaller peak of cases in October corresponding to host seeking by adult ticks (37, 39, 45).

While passive surveillance via national reporting provides important information for estimating disease risk in different geographic regions of the United States, it likely underestimates the true prevalence of anaplasmosis, since it relies on voluntary reporting by health care systems and may not capture cases of subclinical or mild disease. Studies using active surveillance methods highlight this disparity. For example, research conducted using sera from residents and blood donors residing in regions of the United States where disease is endemic has reported seroprevalence rates of 0.5% (Wisconsin blood donors), 3.5% (Connecticut blood donors), 5.1% (children living in Westchester County, NY, being tested for an endocrinologic disorder), 11.3% (Westchester County, NY, blood donors), and 14.9% (Wisconsin residents) (52–54). Of note, none of the 14.9% of Wisconsin residents with positive serology results had a history suggestive of anaplasmosis, indicating that their infections were mild or subclinical, and there was no association between the test result and history of tick bite (52). Other studies have shown higher seropositivity rates in patients with evidence of tick bites, with 35.6% of adults living in Westchester County and 23.3% of specimens submitted to a large reference laboratory in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, for Lyme disease testing being positive for antibodies reacting with A. phagocytophilum (53, 55). In Europe, reported seroprevalence rates in blood donors range from 0 to 2.9%, with higher rates (1.5 to 21%) in individuals reporting tick exposure (42).

A. phagocytophilum DNA has been detected from a wide range of mammals and birds, and this organism is a known pathogen of humans, dogs, horses, and several wild and domestic ruminants (16, 56). Some of these animals have been demonstrated to serve as competent reservoir hosts. The primary reservoir hosts of A. phagocytophilum are small mammals such as white-footed mice (Peromyscus leucopus), chipmunks (Tamias striatus), voles (Clethrionomys gapperi), and other wild rodents (16). Although white-tailed deer can be persistently infected by A. phagocytophilum, the strains (AP variant 1) that naturally infect deer are not infectious for small mammals, have not been identified in humans, and likely represent nonpathogenic variants (57). Persistent or prolonged infection in animal reservoir hosts is essential for maintenance of zoonoses like anaplasmosis. Mice infected with A. phagocytophilum can remain infected for months, and this contributes to its transmission to different stages of developing I. scapularis ticks (58). In Europe, red deer, sheep, cattle, and goats are persistently infected and serve as reservoirs of A. phagocytophilum.
Other species ofAnaplasma have been described to infect humans; Anaplasma capra was detected among 28 patients in China, and a single patient was infected with Anaplasma ovis in Cyprus (59, 60).

sect1.title: Human Ehrlichiosis
sect1.para: Most cases of human ehrlichiosis occur in the United States, where the three primary causative agents areE. chaffeensis, E. ewingii, and E. muris subsp. eauclairensis. Other Ehrlichia species, including the Panola Mountain Ehrlichia species and E. canis, have also been reported to cause human disease in the United States and other regions of the world (61, 62); significant human pathogens are outlined in Table 1. Although infections have previously been named based on the primary cell type infected (e.g., human monocytic ehrlichiosis [HME]), the preference is now to designate the type of disease based on the causative agent (e.g., E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis) in order to avoid confusion. E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis is the most common form of ehrlichiosis in the United States (38, 45).

Ehrlichiosis is transmitted almost exclusively through the bite of infected ticks.E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis is transmitted to humans by Amblyomma americanum (the lone star tick), an aggressive hard-bodied tick that indiscriminately feeds on a wide range of hosts, including humans (45). This tick also transmits E. ewingii. A. americanum is one of the most commonly encountered ticks in the southeastern United States and has a range that extends into New England and the Upper Midwest. Its range overlaps that of I. scapularis in many areas, and thus, patients with tick exposure can be at risk from pathogens transmitted by both tick species. In comparison to E. chaffeensis and E. ewingii, E. muris subsp. eauclairensis is transmitted to humans by I. scapularis (63). Less commonly, human ehrlichiosis can be transmitted through solid organ transplantation and blood transfusion (48, 64–66).

The first cases ofE. chaffeensis, E. ewingii, and E. muris subsp. eauclairensis ehrlichiosis were documented in 1991, 1999, and 2011, respectively (63, 67, 68). E. muris subsp. eauclairensis was initially referred to as the Ehrlichia muris-like agent due to its genetic similarities to Ehrlichia muris found in Eurasia (69). While ehrlichiosis has been a nationally notifiable disease in the United States since 1999, it was only in 2008 that the case definition was refined to differentiate infection with E. chaffeensis, E. ewingii, and A. phagocytophilum (previously classified as an Ehrlichia species) (38, 40).

According to data reported to the CDC, 4,613 cases ofE. chaffeensis infection and 55 cases of E. ewingii infection occurred during 2008 to 2012, representing incidence rates of 3.2 and 0.04 cases per million person-years, respectively (38). There were 2,093 cases reported in 2019, which represents a 10-fold increase in ehrlichiosis cases since 2000 (40). Cases of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis are most frequently reported from the south-central and southeastern United States, extending from Texas to the East Coast (40). Missouri, Arkansas, North Carolina, and New York accounted for nearly 50% of reported cases in 2019. The incidence rate increased with age, with the highest rate occurring among individuals 65 to 69 years of age (40). Males accounted for the majority of cases.

From 2008 to 2012, there were only 55 reported cases ofE. ewingii ehrlichiosis. Cases were reported from 12 states, with 69% reported from Missouri, Delaware, and Tennessee (38). Incidence rates increased with age, with individuals 65 years and older having the highest rate compared to other members of the population. Males accounted for 51% of cases (38). There have now been 261 cases of E. ewingii ehrlichiosis reported from 2008 to 2019 (40).

In contrast to anaplasmosis, human ehrlichiosis due toE. chaffeensis and E. ewingii does not have a bimodal distribution. Most cases occur during May through August, with peak occurrences in June (E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis) and July (E. ewingii ehrlichiosis) (38).

To date,E. muris subsp. eauclairensis has been detected only in patients exposed to ticks in Minnesota and Wisconsin (70) and has not been detected in patient specimens collected outside Minnesota and Wisconsin (63, 70, 71). While most positive ticks have been from Minnesota and Wisconsin, E. muris subsp. eauclairensis was recently detected in an I. scapularis tick collected in Menominee County, Michigan (72), and this agent was also detected in an Ixodes muris tick collected in 2011 in Manitoba (R. Lindsay and A. Dibernardo, personal communication). Furthermore, a distinct clade of E. muris has been detected in Ixodes cookei ticks collected in Maine and New York states (73). The public health significance of this finding is unclear.

Sixty-nine cases ofE. muris subsp. eauclairensis ehrlichiosis have been reported in a case series spanning 2007 to 2013 (70), and additional human cases continue to be detected in patients with exposure to ticks in the Upper Midwest (74).

A significant limiting factor for national ehrlichiosis reporting in the United States is that case definitions are based largely on serologic testing, which exhibits significant cross-reactivity amongEhrlichia species due to antigenic similarity. A high level of serologic cross-reactivity with A. phagocytophilum is also observed. Thus, serologic test results must be interpreted in the context of clinical and epidemiologic features. Most reports of E. chaffeensis human and canine infection from the Upper Midwest, for example, likely reflect E. muris subsp. eauclairensis infection given that I. scapularis is the primary tick vector of human diseases in this state (38, 56, 75). Also, cases of E. ewingii ehrlichiosis must be PCR positive to meet the case definition, and cases tested only by serologic methods may be incorrectly classified as E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis.

As with anaplasmosis, passive surveillance methods could significantly underestimate the true incidence of human ehrlichiosis (76). Prospective evaluation of heavily exposed cohorts shows that approximately 75% of seroconversions are subclinical, and thus, many infected individuals might not undergo testing to evaluate for ehrlichiosis (77). The diagnosis could also be missed when appropriate testing is not ordered. A retrospective seroprevalence study testing residual sera from children (ages 1 to 17 years) submitted in 1999 for any reason to seven academic pediatric medical centers in the southeastern and south-central United States detected antibodies reacting with E. chaffeensis (titers of 80 or higher) in 13% (78). The positivity rate ranged from 2% (Louisville, KY) to 22% (Winston-Salem, NC).

White-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) are the primary reservoirs for E. chaffeensis and E. ewingii, with domestic dogs also serving as reservoirs (36, 79, 80). Birds and mammals that host Amblyomma ticks could also serve as minor reservoirs (81). In addition to their role as a reservoir, domestic dogs also serve as transport hosts by bringing infected A. americanum ticks into close proximity to human households (82). The full spectrum of reservoirs for E. muris subsp. eauclairensis is not yet known, but white-footed mice are known to be an important reservoir (83, 84). This organism was not detected in a convenience sampling of blood from 181 white-tailed deer killed in Camp Ripley, Minnesota, during the 2010 archery season (14 September to 31 December) (84).

sect1.title: Neorickettsiosis (Sennetsu Fever)
sect1.para: Named after the Japanese term for glandular fever,Neorickettsia sennetsu was first identified from a Japanese patient with suspected infectious mononucleosis in 1953 (85) and has since been reported from patients in the Southeast Asian countries of Malaysia, Thailand, and Laos (31, 86). Neorickettsia species are thought to be transmitted to vertebrate hosts through ingestion of infected trematodes in undercooked fish and aquatic insects (8). While ingestion of the gray mullet, Mugil cephalus, was implicated in the index case of human neorickettsiosis, and N. sennetsu DNA has been detected in the climbing perch, Anabas testudineus, the bacterium has yet to be detected in trematodes (8, 31, 87). This is in contrast to the related organisms Neorickettsia helminthoeca (agent of salmon poisoning disease of canids) and N. risticii (agent of Potomac horse fever), which have been found in all stages of nematode hosts (8), although the entire genome of a Neorickettsia sp. highly syntenic with N. sennetsu and N. risticii was identified in Fasciola hepatica from Oregon and Uruguay (87).

Human infection is rare, with fewer than 100 cases reported worldwide as of 2015 (88). However, antibodies reacting with N. sennetsu have been reported in a relatively high percentage (17%) of adults in Laos and 0.2 to 4% of febrile patients in Thailand, suggesting that both infections may be underrecognized (31, 86).

sect1.title: Neoehrlichiosis
sect1.para: Neoehrlichiosis is an emerging tick-borne human infection in Europe and Asia caused by “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” (89–91). The first reported human case was in a Swedish man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia in 2010, more than a decade after the organism was recognized in Dutch I. ricinus ticks (6, 89). “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” has also been detected in I. persulcatus and other ticks (89).

Cases have now been reported involving more than 100 patients in Europe and China (91). The reservoirs for “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” are small mammals, including field mice and voles, in both Europe and Asia (89, 90).

sect1.title: Human Granulocytic Anaplasmosis
sect1.para: Anaplasmosis most commonly presents as a nonspecific acute febrile illness following a 5- to 11-day incubation period after a bite from an infected tick. The full clinical spectrum ranges from subclinical or mildly symptomatic illness, to severe, life-threatening disease, and there is a direct correlation between disease severity and patient age and/or presence of comorbidities (37). Symptomatic patients most commonly complain of fever (up to 100%), malaise (97%), headache (82%), myalgias (76%), and arthralgia (56%) (41). Gastrointestinal, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and central nervous system involvement occurs in fewer than half of patients. Rash has been observed in only 6% of patients and in all cases could be attributable to concurrent Lyme disease with erythema migrans (41). Meningoencephalitis is rarely reported (0.9% of cases) in anaplasmosis (37); however, other reported neurologic sequelae include facial diplegia, brachial plexopathy, and demyelinating polyneuropathy (92). Additional manifestations of severe disease include myocarditis, hepatitis, interstitial pneumonitis, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis syndrome, and adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (93).

The most common laboratory findings are increased serum transaminase activity (83%), thrombocytopenia (75%), and leukopenia (55%) with lymphopenia. Lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes can occur after the first week of infection (94, 95). Anemia is less common, being reported in only 28% (41). Elevated levels of C-reactive protein occur in 96 to 100% and can be helpful in differentiating this disease from viral infections (96, 97). Cerebral spinal fluid analysis is usually unremarkable, even in patients with suspected central nervous system manifestations (98).

Data from cases occurring in the United States during 2008 to 2012 showed that 1,827 of 5,937 patients (31%) for which data were available had disease severe enough to warrant hospitalization (37). Among 2,825 cases with available data, 0.3% to 3% involved life-threatening complications such as renal failure, ARDS, meningitis or encephalitis, pneumonia, disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC), and sepsis (37). Another case analysis reported life-threatening complications in 7% of identified patients (99). Reported case fatality rates vary. A subset of 16 patients from one region of China had significantly greater disease severity (including multiorgan dysfunction, gastrointestinal, renal, and hemorrhagic manifestations, and worse laboratory features) and a case fatality rate of 16%, whereas the case fatality rate was 2.6% among 46 other patients with anaplasmosis in Shandong Province and is 0.3% in the United States (37, 100). There is some evidence that the cases in China reflect greater severity owing to concurrent infection by a tick-borne bunyavirus (101). In the United States, the highest case fatality rates have been observed in patients aged 70 or older (37).

sect1.title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis Ehrlichiosis
sect1.para: As with anaplasmosis, the spectrum of clinical presentations ofE. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis ranges from subclinical infection to life-threatening disease (99). The median incubation period for HME is 9 days. Patients most commonly present with fever (97%), malaise (82%), headache (80%), myalgia (57%), and nausea (64%), without localizing physical findings (99). Other gastrointestinal (vomiting and diarrhea), respiratory (cough), and osteoarticular (joint pain) symptoms are present in less than 50% of patients (99). In comparison to anaplasmosis, petechial, macular, and maculopapular rashes occur with varied distribution and onset (102) and are most frequent in children (57% of cases) but occur in <30% of adults (40, 103). Central nervous system involvement is also well described, with stiff neck and confusion seen in 3% and 19% of cases, respectively (99, 104). Patients with E. chaffeensis can also develop hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis syndrome (105, 106).

Abnormal laboratory parameters occur in at least 86% of patients and include increased serum transaminase levels (83%), thrombocytopenia (71%), and leukopenia (62%) with lymphopenia and/or neutropenia (99).

OfE. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis cases occurring in the United States during 2008 to 2012, 57% were severe enough to warrant hospitalization, with 11% having life-threatening complications such as renal failure, ARDS, meningitis or encephalitis, pneumonia, DIC, and sepsis (37). Corresponding case fatality rates were fortunately low (1%). Other reports describe severe complications occurring in 9 to 17% of patients (99). Fulminant infections are more common in patients immunocompromised by HIV, high-dose corticosteroids, medications related to organ transplantation or specific immune suppression (e.g., rituximab), and diabetes (38, 107–110). Of the cases reported in the United States during 2008 to 2012, 14% were in patients with an immunocompromising condition (38). The case fatality rate in the latter group was 0.7 to 1%, with the highest rates observed in children <5 years of age and adults ≥70 years of age (38). Previously reported risk factors for death are male sex, advanced age, immunosuppression, delayed diagnosis, and lack of early treatment (111, 112).

sect1.title: Ehrlichia ewingii Ehrlichiosis
sect1.para: Symptoms ofE. ewingii ehrlichiosis are similar to those of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis and include fever, headache, myalgia, and malaise (45). Thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and increased hepatic transaminase levels are common laboratory findings. Of the 52 cases occurring in the United States during 2008 to 2012 for which data were available, 40 (77%) patients had disease severe enough to warrant hospitalization (38). There were no reported fatalities. Data regarding immune status were available for 38 patients, of which 10 (26%) had an immunocompromising condition (38). This differs from earlier reports of E. ewingii ehrlichiosis that primarily involved immunocompromised patients.

sect1.title: Ehrlichia muris subsp. eauclairensis
sect1.para: From the limited data available, the clinical features of infection withEhrlichia muris subsp. eauclairensis seem similar to those of other ehrlichioses, with fever, malaise, headache, and myalgia being the predominant reported symptoms (seen in 89%, 76%, 67%, and 60% of patients, respectively) (70). The most commonly observed laboratory values are elevated liver transaminases (78%), thrombocytopenia (67%), lymphopenia (53%), leukopenia (39%), and anemia (36%). No fatalities have been reported to date.

sect1.title: Neorickettsia sennetsu
sect1.para: Patients with neorickettsiosis develop a self-limited febrile illness with chills, headache, malaise, sore throat, anorexia, and generalized lymphadenopathy (88). Laboratory findings include early leukopenia and atypical lymphocytes in the peripheral blood during early convalescence. No fatalities or severe complications have been reported (88).

sect1.title: “Candidatus Neoehrlichia mikurensis”
sect1.para: There have been several reports of human neoehrlichiosis published to date (89, 91). A 2015 review described 26 human cases, comprising 12 immunocompromised and 14 immunocompetent patients. These 12 cases involving immunocompromised patients were characterized by high fever (12/12), myalgias/arthralgias (8/12), vascular/thromboembolic events (6/12), weight loss (5/12), and rash (4/12) (89). Vascular events included deep vein thromboses, pulmonary embolism, transient ischemic attacks, and lower extremity edema (89). The 14 cases involving immunocompetent patients had a more variable clinical presentation, ranging from asymptomatic infection in five Polish patients to a fatal case in Germany. Additionally, seven immunocompetent hosts from China experienced fever (7/7), myalgia/arthralgia (4/7), and rash (1/7) (89). Host factors associated with severe illness in this review include advanced age and immunocompromised condition, including splenectomy (89). More recently, Höper and colleagues described a cohort of 40 Swedish patients diagnosed during 2009 to 2019 (91). The median patient age was 61 years, and there was an equal gender distribution. Of note, the majority (30/40 [75%]) of the patients were immunocompromised, and 60% experienced vascular complications, including 19 of the 30 immunocompromised patients (91). Most vascular events were venous in origin and included deep vein thrombosis (exclusively in immunocompromised patients), recurrent thrombophlebitis, and pulmonary embolism. Three of the 30 patients, all immunocompetent, experienced arteritis (91).

sect1.title: Contributions of Wolbachia to Human Disease
sect1.para: Although bloodstream infection by aWolbachia species associated only with insects was reported in a febrile patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma (113), Wolbachia spp. have not yet been shown to be directly pathogenic for humans or animals. However, evidence indicates a potential role for release of intracellular Wolbachia components from filarial helminths such as Brugia malayi, Onchocerca volvulus, and Wuchereria bancrofti while in their human hosts. In theory, these microbial components act as potentiators of inflammation and contribute to lymphatic obstruction associated with filarial infections (114). At a minimum, the endosymbionts are mutualists on which the helminths depend to enable survival from stage to stage.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: The most commonly used methods for diagnosis of infection with members of theAnaplasmataceae are nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), serology, and microscopic examination of peripheral blood films for the presence of morulae (45, 115). This section focuses on collection of specimens for detection of A. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia species.

For serologic confirmation of anaplasmosis and ehrlichiosis, testing of at least two serum specimens is recommended: one obtained during acute illness and a second during the convalescence period, 2 to 4 weeks later (45). Testing of a single serum sample, particularly if it was collected during the acute phase, may be of limited clinical utility, as antibodies are frequently undetectable or at low titers during this time, and regional high seroprevalence makes it difficult to differentiate between recent and past infection. Specimens should be collected in a specific transport device (e.g., clot tube or serum separator tube [SST]) and transported to the laboratory at room temperature within 2 h of collection (116). Most serologic testing for these pathogens is performed at reference laboratories, which require longer transport times. If referral testing is necessary, centrifuged SSTs or serum aliquoted from the clot tube should be sent refrigerated or frozen (116).

EDTA-anticoagulated whole blood is the preferred specimen for NAATs and blood smears for detection ofA. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia spp., as these are intracellular pathogens infecting leukocytes. Therefore, serum and plasma should not be used for these methods. Whole blood should be obtained during the active phase of illness, ideally before the start of antibiotic therapy (45, 99, 116–118). Samples should be obtained by sterile venipuncture and tested promptly by NAAT or frozen at −20 to −80°C for future testing (45, 116). For blood smears, acute-phase peripheral blood buffy coat smears may be employed to increase the number of leukocytes examined on the slide; these should be prepared within hours of obtaining the sample, since leukocytes degenerate rapidly (45, 98). Once prepared, air-dried blood smears and cytocentrifuged cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) preparations are stable at room temperature for months or years.

Whole blood is also the preferred specimen for culture ofEhrlichia and Anaplasma species, although culture is typically performed only at public health or research laboratories. Similar to NAAT, samples for culture should be obtained by sterile venipuncture and processed as soon as possible or maintained at 4°C during shipping/storage, without freezing. A. phagocytophilum is easier to culture than E. chaffeensis and can be grown from EDTA-anticoagulated blood stored for up to 18 days at 4°C (119). Following isolation, Ehrlichia spp. and A. phagocytophilum can be stored frozen within infected host cells at −80°C for months and in liquid nitrogen for longer intervals for maintained viability. Storage of infected cells is best accomplished when more than 50 to 90% of the host cells are infected, and it is achieved by suspension of at least 106 cells per ml in tissue culture medium that contains 5 to 10% dimethyl sulfoxide and 10 to 45% fetal bovine serum (120, 121).

sect2.title: LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS
sect2.para: Testing forA. phagocytophilum and/or Ehrlichia species may not be available at the local clinical laboratory, particularly in settings where these organisms are not endemic, but is generally available at reference and public health laboratories (122). It is important to note that infections can be rapidly fatal and the results of diagnostic assays are rarely available at the time of initial patient management. Therefore, therapeutic decisions, including empiric therapy, often need to be made before test results are available (45, 112, 115).

The methods used for laboratory diagnosis of anaplasmosis and ehrlichiosis vary significantly in their performance characteristics, availability, and time required to obtain results. Serodiagnosis, molecular amplification, and blood smear examination are used most commonly. Culture is rarely employed in the clinical laboratory but may be offered by specialized reference or public health laboratories (116). The recommended diagnostic tests for A. phagocytophilum and E. chaffeensis are outlined in Table 2. Note that the sensitivity of each method varies by the time in the course of infection and that different tests may be preferred during early and late stages of infection (45, 115, 123). In general, NAAT and blood smear examination provide the highest sensitivity during the first week of illness, while serologic testing offers the highest sensitivity during convalescence (10, 45, 123). Testing for A. phagocytophilum and E. chaffeensis should be conducted in facilities using biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) practices with standard precautions.

sect2.title: Microscopy by Romanowsky Staining of Peripheral Blood
sect2.para: Examination of Giemsa- or Wright-stained peripheral blood or buffy coat leukocytes for the presence of characteristic intracellular morulae within granulocytes is a highly valuable, albeit inconsistent, technique in the diagnosis of anaplasmosis (45, 99), with reported sensitivities of 25% to 75% (123, 124). Examination of monocytes is a significantly less sensitive method for detection of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis, with sensitivities ranging from 2 to 38% (124, 125). With both pathogens, accurate detection of morulae is highly operator dependent and should be performed by skilled and experienced microscopists (45). Usually, 800 to 1,000 granulocytes or monocytes are examined under magnifications of ×500 to ×1,000 for the presence of morulae (126), although a study of anaplasmosis revealed that as few as 200 neutrophils was sufficient to detect positive smears (127). Since most patients presenting with positive smears have <1% infected cells and usually have leukopenia, buffy coat preparations will yield more than peripheral smears. Morulae of E. chaffeensis are most commonly identified from immunocompromised individuals. The number of detectable infected leukocytes in peripheral blood correlates modestly with severity of infection (94, 128, 129); the reported percentage of cells infected with E. chaffeensis ranges from 0.2% to 10% and can reach 40% or higher with A. phagocytophilum (128).

Morulae are small (1- to 3-μm diameter), round to oval cohesive clusters of small bacteria that stain basophilic to amphophilic with Romanowsky stains (Fig. 2). These clusters are present within vacuoles in the cytoplasm of granulocytes (anaplasmosis) or monocytes (E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis) and have a stippled appearance owing to individual bacteria within the vacuole. Various structures such as leukocyte toxic granulations, phagocytosed bacteria and yeasts, Döhle bodies, nuclear fragments, Auer rods, and overlying platelets can have a similar appearance and must be differentiated from true morulae (45).

sect2.title: Immunochemistry for Antigen Detection
sect2.para: Immunochemical methods can also be used to identifyA. phagocytophilum and E. chaffeensis in cytological preparations (e.g., cytocentrifuged CSF) or within formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded human tissue, including bone marrow, liver, and spleen, and may be of particular utility for confirming the diagnosis in specimens obtained at autopsy (124, 130, 131). Sensitivity and specificity have not been determined for detection of A. phagocytophilum, while the sensitivity of detecting active E. chaffeensis infection with examination of bone marrow is only 40% (124). A monoclonal antibody can specifically detect E. chaffeensis in human tissues (132), but most studies use polyclonal antibodies which react with other Ehrlichia species. Commercial assays for these organisms are not currently available.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Amplification Tests
sect2.para: Amplification and detection of DNA extracted from whole-blood specimens constitute a highly accurate method for laboratory diagnosis of acuteA. phagocytophilum and E. chaffeensis infection, with sensitivities equal to or exceeding that of culture and blood smear evaluation (45, 99). PCR is the most common amplification modality in these tests.

sect3.title: Anaplasma phagocytophilum
sect3.para: Multiple PCR assays for detection ofA. phagocytophilum nucleic acids have been published, including conventional and real-time methods (63, 133–136). PCR is at least as sensitive as blood smears for detection of morulae in the first 14 days after onset of illness and is more sensitive for a longer period of time (>14 to ≤30 days) after illness onset (123). Many protocols utilize amplification of the 16S rRNA gene. A frequently applied and evaluated conventional method employs primers to amplify a 919-bp 16S rRNA gene fragment, usually in a single-stage reaction with or without a hybridization probe to enhance sensitivity (12, 134). A previously popular alternative uses nested PCR with an outer set of primers to amplify bacterial 16S rRNA genes, followed by PCR with internal nested A. phagocytophilum-specific primers (104, 135). In studies conducted prior to the development of real-time PCR, the analytical sensitivity and specificity of several published primer sets were evaluated using DNA extracted from serial dilutions of A. phagocytophilum-infected HL-60 cells (135). Specificity was evaluated using DNA extracted from cultures of E. chaffeensis, Rickettsia rickettsii, and Bartonella henselae. The primer sets with the greatest sensitivity and specificity were those used in nested PCR to amplify the 16S rRNA gene and those amplifying msp2 (135). Both PCR assays detected as few as 50 infected cells/mL. Real-time PCR assays provide increased sensitivity to as few as 1 infected cell per microliter of blood. One described multiplex real-time TaqMan reverse transcriptase PCR targeting the 16S rRNA gene detects 3 Ehrlichia and 2 Anaplasma spp. and has an analytical sensitivity of 100 16S rRNA copies (approximately 1 infected cell in a test sample) (133). Another described multiplex real-time assay with similar analytical sensitivity targets Anaplasmataceae groEL and uses hybridization probes and melting temperature analysis to detect and differentiate E. chaffeensis, E. ewingii, E. muris, and A. phagocytophilum (123, 137). More recently, a novel high-definition multiplex PCR assay for 12 tick-borne pathogens (ChromaCode, Carlsbad, CA), including A. phagocytophilum (rpoB gene target) and 3 Ehrlichia species (three different outer membrane protein gene targets), was evaluated using 530 whole-blood samples (138). The authors showed identical sensitivity for detection of A. phagocytophilum compared to a conventional, single-target PCR assay, with the added benefit of testing for multiple pathogens simultaneously. While there are currently no tests for in vitro diagnosis cleared or approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), some CE-marked kits are available, including those by Liferiver (Brussels, Belgium), EliGene (Czech Republic), and Bioron Diagnostics (Ludwigshafen, Germany), and InterLabService (Moscow, Russia) markets a multiplex pathogen kit (AmpliSens) for detection of B. burgdorferi, A. phagocytophilum, E. chaffeensis, and E. muris. Kits designated for research use only (RUO) are also commercially available.

sect3.title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis
sect3.para: There are a large number of potential gene targets for molecular detection of infection withE. chaffeensis, with PCR sensitivities ranging from 60% to 100% (82, 104, 117). The most widely used method is PCR amplification of DNA from E. chaffeensis in clinical samples using the HE1/HE3 primer set (104, 139, 140). This primer pair amplifies a 389-bp fragment of the 16S rRNA gene. The product can then be detected by simple nucleic acid staining (e.g., ethidium bromide) after agarose gel electrophoresis, by Southern hybridization of the amplified products using an internal probe, or preferably by real-time PCR (141). A clinical evaluation of E. chaffeensis PCR targeting the 16S rRNA gene showed a sensitivity of 79 to 100% compared with that of serology; however, nucleic acids from E. chaffeensis were frequently detected in patients who never developed antibodies due to collection of sera during the acute stage of disease (104, 140). A nested PCR assay with 16S rRNA gene primers followed by a second (nested) reaction on whole blood yielded results similar to those obtained by culture (104). More recently, using a multiplex quantitative real-time PCR assay for detection of multiple vector-borne pathogens, including targeting the vlpt gene from E. chaffeensis, Reller and Dumler documented high sensitivity (84%) and excellent specificity (100%) for ehrlichiosis across different blood fractions collected during the acute febrile period (142). Other targets for PCR that have not been fully evaluated for clinical sensitivity or specificity include the outer-surface variable-length PCR target protein gene present in E. chaffeensis (104, 108, 136), the TRP120 gene, which encodes an immunodominant antigen with tandemly repeated subunits that vary among E. chaffeensis isolates, the quinolinate synthase A gene (nadA), the disulfide bond formation protein gene (dsb), and the p28 multigene family (108, 136, 143, 144).

Real-time PCR assays have also been developed that exhibit extremely high analytical sensitivity and specificity comparable to those of nested PCR (133, 143). Advantages of real-time over conventional PCR include improved specificity (lower risk of contamination), increased speed to result, lower cost, and the ability to detect multiple Anaplasmataceae pathogens simultaneously. A broad-range real-time PCR assay that targets groEL of E. chaffeensis, A. phagocytophilum, and E. ewingii has shown excellent clinical sensitivity and specificity and also detects E. muris (63, 137). While there are currently no FDA-cleared or -approved tests, CE-marked kits are available, including those by Bioron Diagnostics (Ludwigshafen, Germany) and InterLabService (Moscow, Russia; multiplex pathogen kit for detection of B. burgdorferi, A. phagocytophilum, E. chaffeensis, and E. muris).

sect3.title: Metagenomic Next-Generation Sequencing
sect3.para: Although not currently a routinely used method,A. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia species have been detected via targeted and shotgun metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) assays (74). The advantage that these assays provide, particularly with respect to shotgun mNGS, include use of a single method to detect multiple cotransmitted pathogens and the potential to identify novel pathogens. The primary challenges to routinely pursuing such testing, however, are the high cost and complexity associated with NGS-based assays, long turnaround times, limited availability, and the absence of FDA-cleared assays for tick-borne pathogens (145). Targeted NGS for bacterial pathogens, including tick-borne agents, involves initial amplification of conserved regions in the 16S rRNA gene, specifically the highly conserved and slowly evolving V1 to V3 regions. Amplicons are subsequently sequenced using NGS methods, with resulting reads assembled and pathogen sequences identified via utilization of different bioinformatic platforms and curated databases. Two targeted NGS methods, amplifying either the V1-V2 or V1-V3 16S rRNA regions, have now been described and have documented both the possibility of detecting bacterial tick-borne pathogens in whole blood, including A. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia species, and the noninferior sensitivity of this approach compared to targeted PCR assays (74, 145, 146).

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures
sect1.para: As mentioned above, culture for these tick-borne pathogens is not used in the clinical microbiology laboratory. BothA. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia spp. are BSL-2 agents. A. phagocytophilum has been cultivated more often from human patients than E. chaffeensis, E. canis, E. muris subsp. eauclairensis, or N. sennetsu, probably owing to the quantity of organisms present in the peripheral blood of infected patients (126). Since A. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia species are bacteria, antibiotics in the medium must be avoided. Instructions for isolation of A. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia spp. can be found in previous editions of this Manual and the published literature (118, 120, 121).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: The gold standard method for serodiagnosis of anaplasmosis andE. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis is demonstration of seroconversion or a 4-fold rise in IgG titers by examination of paired (acute- and convalescent-phase) sera using indirect immunofluorescence assays (IFAs). The IFA employs slides with individual wells containing A. phagocytophilum- or E. chaffeensis-infected cells, which are incubated with patient sera. If present, specific antibodies in the serum sample bind to the bacterial antigens and are subsequently detected using a fluorescently labeled secondary antibody. The test is interpreted visually by technologists using fluorescent microscopy, which can be subjective and therefore requires significant training and expertise. Samples in each well are interpreted as positive if (i) the fluorescent output is of sufficient intensity compared to controls, (ii) the appropriate proportion of infected cells have reactivity, and (iii) a characteristic fluorescence pattern (i.e., clumps representative of classic intracytoplasmic morulae) is observed (Fig. 3). Samples are typically screened at one or two dilutions, after which positive samples are serially diluted to achieve an endpoint titer. As with most serologic assays, sensitivity is low during the first week of infection (Table 2), which is when most patients present for medical evaluation (45). Sensitivity increases with time, however, with most individuals being seropositive 2 to 3 weeks after symptom onset.

There is significant antibody cross-seroreactivity betweenEhrlichia species, and also between antibodies to A. phagocytophilum and E. chaffeensis, although titers of antibody to the infecting bacterium are generally higher. Thus, screening for antibodies against both bacteria is recommended when anaplasmosis or E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis is suspected. IgG-class antibodies can persist for months to years after resolution of infection and may be found in a high percentage of healthy individuals living in areas of endemicity (45).

sect1.title: Anaplasma phagocytophilum
sect1.para: The preferred method for serologic testing of human sera is the use of HL-60 promyelocyte cells infected with a humanA. phagocytophilum isolate (118, 147–151). Commercial sources of IFA serodiagnostic kits include Focus Diagnostics (DiaSorin Molecular LLC, Cypress, CA), Scimedx Corporation (Dover, NJ), Biocell Diagnostics (Baltimore, MD), and Fuller Laboratories (Fullerton, CA); the assays are not FDA cleared or approved in the United States, although they are CE marked. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and immunoblot methods for serodiagnosis have been described (10, 147, 150); however, they are not routinely used due to limited understanding of their performance characteristics and availability. Also, technologies that use immunoblot confirmation or commercially prepared recombinant A. phagocytophilum Msp2 proteins or peptides in devices that enable rapid detection have been employed for serologic diagnosis in veterinary laboratories, but they have not been evaluated for diagnosis of human infections (152, 153). Although anti-A. phagocytophilum IgM and IgG IFA kits are available, IgG testing is most beneficial. IgM testing is potentially useful for identification of recent infection, but neither the sensitivity nor the specificity is as high as that for testing paired sera for IgG, and questions about IgM specificity led the CDC to discourage its use as a single test (154). As a result, and because of the availability and increased sensitivity of PCR assays during acute infection, IgM testing is not commonly used or recommended (151).

For IgG testing, sera are typically screened at a single dilution (1:64 or 1:80), and if specimens are reactive, they are serially diluted to determine the endpoint titer. A serodiagnostic confirmation is achieved when a 4-fold rise in titer is demonstrated in convalescent-phase sera, with a minimum IgG titer of ≥1:128 (115). Demonstration of a single high IgG antibody titer (≥1:128, or higher for residents of regions of endemicity) in a patient with typical clinical features of anaplasmosis may also be used to support a diagnosis of anaplasmosis (129, 155). Approximately 25 to 45% of infected patients have antibodies at the time of presentation (129, 149, 155, 156); however, in regions where anaplasmosis is endemic, up to 11 to 14% of the population possess antibodies, rendering a single serologic test less useful (52, 53). The typical response during acute infection is a rapid rise (within 2 weeks of onset) in antibody levels, reaching high titers (≥1:640) within the first month (149, 156). In treated patients whose diagnoses were confirmed by culture, antibody titers declined gradually over several months, and about half had antibodies detectable by IFA 1 year after infection. However, many patients have antibodies detectable for months to years after initial infection (156).

The sensitivity and specificity of the anaplasmosis serologic tests are both believed to be high because of good correlation between typical clinical cases and serologic reactions toA. phagocytophilum group antigens (129, 149, 156). Seroconversion was documented for 21 of 23 patients (91.3%) with culture-confirmed anaplasmosis, from whom a convalescent-phase sample was available (149). In an inter- and intralaboratory evaluation, paired serology had a median sensitivity of 95% for the detection of acute anaplasmosis in a group of 28 patients diagnosed by culture, PCR, or the presence of morulae in blood smears (151). Of note, patients with anaplasmosis have serologic reactions to E. chaffeensis in up to 15% of cases but often show the higher titers with A. phagocytophilum antigens (129, 151).

Cross-reactivity in theA. phagocytophilum IFA may occur in patients infected with other rickettsiae, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever), and Epstein-Barr virus. Importantly, due to geographic cocirculation of many tick-borne pathogens, which are carried by the same tick vectors, the risk of cotransmission of A. phagocytophilum and other tick-borne pathogens is not insignificant. Across studies, the frequency of A. phagocytophilum and Lyme disease coinfections ranges from 2.3% to 13%, depending on diagnostic criteria and region (157, 158). As a result, antibodies to multiple agents are common in individuals living in areas of high endemicity (52, 159). Autoantibodies to platelets and other leukocyte components can cause false-positive IFA tests for many pathogens, including A. phagocytophilum (160). Prescreening for autoantibodies or routine removal of rheumatoid factors will lessen the risk of misinterpretation due to antibodies reactive with cellular components, including nuclear or cytoplasmic antigens that could have the morphologic appearance of morulae. Finally, antigenic diversity exists among isolates of A. phagocytophilum but is not generally thought to affect antibody detection in clinical specimens (151, 161).

sect1.title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis
sect1.para: Similar toA. phagocytophilum, antibodies against E. chaffeensis are most commonly detected by IFA. The cell type usually employed is E. chaffeensis Arkansas strain-infected DH82 canine macrophage-like cells. Originally, E. canis was used to detect serologic responses to E. chaffeensis due to the known serologic cross-reactivity between the two species; however, IFA reagents for use with E. chaffeensis-infected cells are now readily available and should be used for clinical testing (162). These include IFA kits from Focus Technologies (DiaSorin Molecular LLC, Cypress, CA), Biocell Diagnostics (Baltimore, MD), Fuller Laboratories (Fullerton, CA), and Scimedx Corporation (Denville, NJ). The role of immunoblots in diagnosis of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis is not well established, and their use cannot be advocated. Alternative methods based on recombinant proteins and synthetic peptides show promise, but these are not commercially available (163–165). As with anaplasmosis, detection of IgG-class antibodies to E. chaffeensis is more beneficial than assessment for IgM-class antibodies. A systematic evaluation of the usefulness of IgM testing has not been conducted, but preliminary data from nine culture-confirmed cases suggest that it might be slightly more sensitive than IgG for the diagnosis of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis during the acute phase (166). However, because of concerns about specificity and the routine availability of more sensitive PCR assays, IgM testing is not currently recommended for routine diagnosis of recent E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis (154).

Similar to the approach forA. phagocytophilum serologic testing, samples are initially screened at a dilution of 1:64 or 1:80 for IgG antibodies to E. chaffeensis. Reactive samples are subsequently serially diluted to determine an endpoint. Seroconversion or a 4-fold increase in IgG antibody titers confirms the diagnosis of E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis. A single high IgG titer, ≥1:128, provides supportive evidence of acute infection in patients with a compatible clinical presentation (115). Acute-phase sera should be obtained at the time of presentation, and convalescent-phase sera are best obtained 3 to 6 weeks thereafter.

The sensitivity and specificity of IFA for the diagnosis of infection withE. chaffeensis have not been clearly established; however they are assumed to be high because of documented correlation between new or rising antibody titers against E. chaffeensis and characteristic clinical findings (77). In the early phase of infection, IFA testing is not sensitive compared to PCR (Table 2) (166). Presumptive false-positive reactions have been detected in patients diagnosed with Rickettsia, C. burnetii, Brucella, Lyme disease, and Epstein-Barr virus infections (162, 167). The presence of autoantibodies can also result in false-positive results.

Antigenic diversity amongE. chaffeensis isolates has been well described (168), but it may not affect the detection of polyclonal antibody responses generated with human infection. Several reports describe patients with suspected E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis who lacked antibody responses, even long after onset of symptoms (104, 140, 169). However, in the few cases in which E. chaffeensis infection was proven by isolation of the agent, patients who survived developed clear convalescent-phase serologic reactions by IFA (68, 104, 108, 169, 170). Hypothetical reasons for false-negative results include infection by antigenically diverse strains (unproven) and abrogation of antibody response by early therapy (104). Antibodies developed following infection with other Ehrlichia species may cross-react in E. chaffeensis IFAs; however, the level of cross-reactivity is not well established or consistent among patients, as most recently documented with identification of E. muris subsp. eauclairensis (63).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES, TREATMENT, AND PREVENTION
sect2.para: Doxycycline is the drug of choice for treatment of rickettsial infections in both children and adults (45, 171). No prospective controlled treatment trials to determine antimicrobial effectiveness for ehrlichiosis or anaplasmosis have been conducted. However, retrospective studies and observations from routine clinical practice demonstrate that patients with E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis defervesce generally within 48 h of therapy with doxycycline (41, 77, 172). Tetracyclines are uniformly bactericidal for Ehrlichia and Anaplasma species, whereas the MIC of chloramphenicol cannot be safely achieved in humans with E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis or anaplasmosis (173–177). Of note, many antibiotics prescribed for undifferentiated fever, such as penicillins, cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, and macrolides, do not inhibit the growth of ehrlichiae in vitro. The rifamycins (rifampin and rifabutin) can achieve effective inhibition or killing of Ehrlichia and Anaplasma species in vitro, and the fluoroquinolones (ofloxacin and levofloxacin) have very low MICs for human isolates of A. phagocytophilum (175, 177). However, at least one report documents recrudescence of infection with A. phagocytophilum after levofloxacin was discontinued, followed by a subsequent clinical response to doxycycline (178–180). Rifampin has been used successfully in patients for whom tetracyclines cannot be used or for whom an alternative is preferred, including pregnant women and children (178, 180). In vitro susceptibility testing by real-time PCR found that E. chaffeensis was susceptible to doxycycline and rifampin and was partially susceptible to the fluoroquinolones. Resistance to macrolides, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and beta-lactam compounds was confirmed (173).

Whereas persistent infections withEhrlichia and Anaplasma species can occur in naturally and experimentally infected animals even after treatment with tetracycline, persistence of these bacteria in humans is rarely documented and is not believed to have any clinical importance (169, 181, 182). Therapy is usually highly effective at eliminating them from the blood of infected humans.

Prevention of human anaplasmosis and ehrlichiosis is through avoidance of tick bites and prompt removal of attached ticks (45). Animal studies suggest that ticks are attached to their host for 24 to 48 h prior to transmission of A. phagocytophilum, and thus, removing ticks as soon as possible may decrease the risk of transmission (45); however, at least one study demonstrated transmission within 4 h of a tick bite (183). No similar data are available for E. chaffeensis or E. ewingii transmission. Multiple measures for prevention of tick bites have been described including use of repellents (e.g., DEET [N,N-diethyl-meta-toluamide]), environmental modifications, and use of protective or permethrin-treated clothing (45). Various ectoparasite control measures are also available for pets and livestock, including the application of topical acaricides (45).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Identification ofEhrlichia and Anaplasma species infections requires clinical suspicion, guided by symptom manifestation and geographic exposure risk, followed by laboratory confirmation. Since rapid specific diagnosis is infrequently possible, empirical therapy with doxycycline should be initiated when the diagnosis is suspected, since delays may lead to increased morbidity and perhaps mortality (45, 112). Collection of diagnostic samples should ideally occur before therapy is initiated, and patients should be encouraged to return for clinical and serologic follow-up 2 to 4 weeks later for collection of a convalescent-phase serum sample.

The presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions within a leukocyte in peripheral blood is helpful when present but lacks sensitivity and specificity (45, 99). If the typical morphology of an Ehrlichia or Anaplasma morula is observed, an assessment as to the hematopoietic lineage that contains morulae should be made and reported.

A positive PCR result should be reported as such, indicating the presence ofE. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum DNA present. Laboratories that use a multiplex or broad-range PCR to identify Ehrlichia species or Anaplasma DNA in blood may also be able detect E. ewingii and E. muris subsp. eauclairensis infection that mimics either anaplasmosis or E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis (63, 67, 138). Broad-range PCR assays targeting the 16S rRNA gene or groEL have also identified infection with “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” in Europe (184).

IFA serologic results should be reported as the endpoint titers of antibodies determined to be reactive forE. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum, including the positive cutoff value used in the laboratory. The gold standard for the diagnosis of E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum infection by serology is a 4-fold increase in IgG titer or documentation of seroconversion with a minimum titer of 1:128 if sample dilutions start at 1:64. An interpretation should indicate whether the titers are considered “significant” or “positive,” preferably based upon a 4-fold increase or 4-fold decrease in titer, although this is not often possible due to the submission of single-time-point samples. When only a single high serum IgG titer is obtained, the laboratory should note that it is supportive, but not confirmed evidence, of infection. The use of IgM titers alone is not advocated to establish a diagnosis, since it is not as sensitive as using IgG alone. It should be noted that infections with E. ewingii and E. muris subsp. eauclairensis may yield serologic patterns considered diagnostic for E. chaffeensis and presumably for A. phagocytophilum as well (45, 63).

Cases of ehrlichiosis and anaplasmosis in the United States should be reported using the CDC’s Tick-Borne Rickettsial Disease Case Report form (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/forms/Tick_TBRD_FILL_508.pdf). For the purpose of surveillance, the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists and CDC developed a case definition that was amended in 2008 to include E. chaffeensis ehrlichiosis (HME), anaplasmosis, E. ewingii infection, and “ehrlichiosis/anaplasmosis—undetermined” (185). According to this definition, a clinically compatible case is one in which the patient presents with any reported fever and one or more of the following: headache, myalgia, anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, or any hepatic transaminase elevation. Definitive confirmation of a clinically compatible case requires (i) a 4-fold change in endpoint titers of IgG to E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum by IFA in paired serum samples, (ii) positive PCR for E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum DNA, (iii) detection of E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum antigen in a biopsy or autopsy sample by immunostaining, or (iv) culture of E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum from a clinical sample. A clinically compatible case with (i) a single IFA titer of ≥1:64 of IgG to E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum or (ii) identification of morulae in monocytes (HME) or neutrophils (anaplasmosis) is classified as probable ehrlichiosis/anaplasmosis. The CDC does not use IgM test results as independent diagnostic support criteria. The diagnosis of E. ewingii, E. muris subsp. eauclairensis, and “Ca. Neoehrlichia mikurensis” infection can be established only by nucleic acid amplification methods, since specific antigens and serologic methods are not available. A diagnosis of “ehrlichiosis or anaplasmosis—undetermined” is used when serological tests cannot distinguish between infection by E. chaffeensis or A. phagocytophilum.

Finally, clinicians should consider the possibility of tick-borne coinfections, particularly in patients who fail to respond to antimicrobial therapy directed toA. phagocytophilum and Ehrlichia species. In particular, Babesia microti and Powassan virus may be transmitted by I. scapularis, the same tick that transmits A. phagocytophilum, and neither infection responds to doxycycline.
We recognize the contributions of J. Stephen Dumler and Megan E. Reller to this chapter.
